title: Best Meal we had in Greece
text: We were staying in a nearby hotel, and wandered in by foot to find a place to eat. Greeks eat normally later in the evening than we do, so we literally had the resturant to our self. So the service was great with ocean front seats. The food was amazing, the portions were huge and the prices were reasonable. Great feel, I actually wish we could have been there when it is was full to get the full experience of the room crowded, but was great nonetheless.

title: Beautiful setting
text: We just wandered to the grounds as they closed, so we didn't get to see the museum - but the temple is located in wetland so there is a great walking trail that leads back to the temple. Even though it was closed you could see it from the fence, if we had more time we probably would have wandered back but too much to do, not enough time.

title: So much potential wasted...
text:
I recognize some of the things I will put in this review will seem nit picky, but they were the things that struck us that had we known we probably would have heavily reconsidered staying here, so why I share them here...

First of all, this had the charm and appearance to be a nice hotel. The common areas inside the hotel are beautiful. The rooms were well appointed and comfortable, and you can tell they were recently renovated. It is an older hotel, so we had a couple problems with the electrical (lights, etc.) but the hotel was responsive in fixing them immediately. We were there in the off season, so the outdoor areas were closed off and there was a lot of construction for preparations of the upcoming tourist season - that's understandable though, but I can't say what those facilities are like because of it. Also be aware the room walls are REALLY thin. We literally could listen to the conversations of the couple in the next room, which wasn't as bad as the fact that we could hear them in the bathroom too (nothing like being woke up at 4am listening to some stranger in the next room peeing into the toilet)... which means they could hear us too, luckily we never ran into each other so we could be embarrassed together.

The customer service was inconsistent. There were some employees who went out of their way to make you feel welcome, and there were there that looked at you as being just another interruption to their day. For example, we asked to move to a water view room, and the response was "No". No explanation, no "sure but an additional charge" (which we would have paid) it was just "No". This was even more odd since we spent a week there and the hotel was a ghost town, we never saw more than 2 people in the restaurant at any given time. While others, were genuinely interested in how we were doing what we did during the day, what we saw, and took an interest in us as a customer and guest.

The spa prices seem out of line for services provided to prices we are accustomed to, but the spa does provide full services, but we did not use the spa so cannot comment on it.

We had two meals at the restaurant, a dinner service and a breakfast service. The dinner menu offers a good variety of Greek dishes, with some other cultural foods beyond Greece for more picky eaters. The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't knock your socks off either. Just standard fare really. Breakfast was a buffet, but was mainly pastries and breads, yogurt (typical Greek breakfast), with 1-2 hot items (egg and bacon). The food wasn't bad for this either, but for 10 euro each we expected more variety than a couple 0.50 euro pastry if you bought it at the store down the street from the hotel, scrambled eggs and bacon.

The hotel grounds is right on the water, but the actual building to where the shoreline is, is not very close. If you go out the hotel, you walk down a hill to get to the shoreline - I didn't really estimate the distance but it took a minute or two to get to the water so it's not a short walk. Also be prepared, you'll have to walk back uphill after spending the time in the sun/water.

For being an "upscale Wyndham Resort", we were not expecting to be "nickle and dimed" for everything. The use of the indoor pool was an additional charge (20 euro), even though exterior pool was closed, breakfast was an additional charge, and so on. In itself wasn't a huge deal, but would have been nice if all of that was disclosed at booking. I guess we just expected more from our other Wyndham stays.

Finally this hotel, is not near Athens proper. If you stay here, you can expect a 30-50 euro transfer each direction, or a two hour bus trip. If you're daring enough to rent a car and drive in Athens, that will be your most time/cost effective way to get from this hotel into Athens proper. So be prepared for the transfer costs, or other options.

Where the hotel is though is right at a Delta, where fresh water river meets the sea. So provides some beautiful views, and a lot of wild life. The town of Vravronas is within walking distance, and has some great little shops, beach access, and restaurants (in fact one of the best meals we had during our time in Greece was right near the hotel).
place: Dolce by Wyndham Athens Attica Riviera

title: You'd regret missing this
text: Most people come to Athens to see, this so don't be that person who misses it. The details are unimaginable, and the scale and beauty of the workmanship makes it worth the uphill walk and crowd surfing.

title: Get your tourist on...
text: This is the place to go for your shopping and dinner. Outdoor shops and restaurants littered through a maze of streets. Definitely need to see it, and get your souvenirs

title: If you can only see 1 thing in Athens, it's this
text: I mean it's iconic, so how could you not. We went in the off season, so the crowds weren't bad - but the history that you're walking along and views are breathtaking. Even if it was a crowded tourist season, you cannot miss this stop.

title: So much information
text: There is a ton of information, and great examples of ruins from the Acropolis that you can get up close to. For me though, the best part of this museum is underneath it - they have ruins of the "middle class" homes and bath houses excavated that you can walk above on platforms, you need to see it.

title: Athena, the goddess of Wisdom, says "take this tour"
text: This was our first stop in Athens. We figured, we needed to have someone walk us through the history of this place before we struck out on our own - and one of the best decisions we made on this trip. Our tour guide was great. Very laid back, and attentive. Spent a lot of time providing us great historical context of the sites of the tour, and how the mythology of antiquity has blended into Athens culture of today, and even into the world. The tour included explanations over the various gods/goddesses in Greek mythology, and the temples/ruins dedicated to them - including what life would have looked like back then. There was no shortage of information, and our tour guide went into detail for any of the questions that our group threw at her - I don't think any of us left with an unanswered question, but we all left with more knowledge than when we started - and also provided my wife and I the building block on what we wanted to spend more time looking at during our time in Athens, and how to create the plan to accomplish all of that!

title: More than the path of illumination
text: Piazza Navona has two fountains, one of them Bernini's. It was a laid back Piazza, allowing you to take in the fountain in a relaxed atmosphere with plenty of opportunities for pictures.

title: A Palace you have not even fathomed...
text: Much of Rome's ancient city, you have to use your imagination to see what it would have looked like all those centuries ago - but you cannot deny the awesome size and intricate detail (such as floor mosaics still in the ground surrounded by grass now) - much of which has only been uncovered in the last 50 years - imagine what you will see when you go back next time?

title: Bucket list location... check
text: We went here in the tourist "off" season, and it was crazy busy. I cannot even fathom during the busy season what it would be like, but the only way to make it through sea of people would be through a skip-the-line tour. Our guide was Giuseppe, and he was great. Had a ton of information, personal stories along with the history tied everything together while getting us in and focusing our attention on the whole experience. It seemed rushed at some parts, but the things you can't miss on the tour (St Peters, Sistine Chapel, etc.) you will have plenty of time to see. If you want to go back into the museums after the tour, you can so you can spend more time on the things that interest you that may have seemed rush - but the tour will give you the roadmap to allow you to know what you want to see, and what you don't want to see.
place: Faster Than Skip-the-Line: Vatican, Sistine Chapel and St. Peter's Basilica Tour

title: Must see...
text: One of those places on earth that you can't be this close and not see it. It's crowded, so don't expect to get a selfie without an unintended photo bomb

title: How to be a tourist in Rome...
text: Beautiful neighborhood, lots of stores and resturants. It is very touristy, you should visit to see it, but if your time is limited in Rome there are better places to go.

title: Walking on the road of antiquity
text: Literally you are walking on the road that predates Christ. You have to use some imagination to envision the glory of the era from the 2700+ year old (that's impressive on it's own) ruins, but once you open up that imagination you are transported back to history and humbled by what man accomplished so long ago.

title: One of many must see...
text: I would suggest the skip the line tours that are out there, espeically in the busy tourist season. You can get through on your own, but it's nice to get a local perspective on the site and learn their history from their perspective not from what we read in a book. Not standing in line is a plus. However, the Colosseum was impressive - so many intricate details that you may not be aware of until you get up close and see for yourself. One of the must sees in Rome.

title: Rome's oldest Catholic Church?
text: There was a line around the Piazza when we got there, and to be honest I was hesitant, but decided to get in line. The line moved quick, took less than 10 minutes before we were in the church. This is an active church, and when we were there one of the recesses has a choir singing while we were visiting. Beautiful building, beautiful art, and still active!

title: Best way to see the Colosseum and surrounding areas
text: Great tour, and the skip the line is a must especially in the busy tourist season. Our guide Giuseppe was very knowledgeable, took the time to explain things to the mixed age group so everyone understood, and did so in a entertaining way so that by the end of the tour you didn't even realize you have been walking all through ancient Rome for a couple hours until it was over.
place: Skip the Line: Colosseum Small Group Tour with Roman Forum & Palatine Hill

title: Great location, comfortable room, great service!
text: Comfortable rooms, in a great neighborhood walking distance to a lot of Rome Sites (and if you're active, it's within walking distance to the entire city). We stayed in two different rooms, and both were comfortable. The real gem of GR House is the owner Georgio, he was amazing. Very attentive and helpful for someone who had never visited the city before. Advice, directions, restaurant recommendations, even helped in arranging airport transfer services. When I go back to Rome, I will stay here again!

title: Think outside the box
text: Second time, first in their new room. Very friendly staff, clean facility, and fun event - great to get outside the box instead of the same boring "movie night"
place: The Escape Key - Salt Lake City
